# Using LIM to predict biomass 

Here is an example with 2 species. First, we load the package.

```{R setup}
library(fwebinfr)
library(ggplot2)
library(patchwork)
```

Then we use an example.

```{R value}
val <- fw_gen_ex1()
val
```

A quick visualisation of the dynamics. 

```{R plot}
fwebinfr:::quick_ode_plot(
    fwebinfr:::mod_lv_fr1, rep(0.3, 2), seq(1, 500, 0.1),
    pars = val
)
```

Then we call `fw_infer()`.

```{R compute}
# custom parameter (see limSolve::xsample())
pars <- c(
    val,
    burninlength = 5000,
    iter = 5000,
    type = "mirror"
)
res <- pars |>
    do.call(what = "fw_infer")
dim(res)
head(res)
```

Visuaizs values ranges

```{R res}
summary(res)
boxplot(res)
```

Let's plot the dynamics for the system with the min and max leading eigen value. 


```{R compare1, fig.height = 10}
p1 <- fwebinfr:::quick_ode_plot(
  fwebinfr:::mod_lv_fr1, rep(0.3, 2), seq(1, 500, 0.1),
  pars = list(
    A = fwebinfr::fw_get_A_predicted(res[which.min(res$leading_ev), ], val$A),
    B = fwebinfr::fw_get_B_predicted(res[which.min(res$leading_ev), ], val$A, val$R),
    R = val$R
  )
) + ggtitle("Minimum leading eigen value")

p2 <- fwebinfr:::quick_ode_plot(
  fwebinfr:::mod_lv_fr1, rep(0.3, 2), seq(1, 500, 0.1),
  pars = list(
    A = fwebinfr::fw_get_A_predicted(res[which.max(res$leading_ev), ], val$A),
    B = fwebinfr::fw_get_B_predicted(res[which.max(res$leading_ev), ], val$A, val$R),
    R = val$R
  )
) + ggtitle("Maximum leading eigen value")
p1 / p2
```
